11:17 am
BE11:17am

AMZN reported revenue 1% below consensus, significantly exceeded on operating income (by 76%), and guided below consensus for 4Q. We don’t see any real structural issue with AMZN but nearly every line in the business is decelerating a tad, and we typically see another deceleration in retail in 4Q, hence are struggling to identify a catalyst. Shares are up 52% YTD, hence this kind of “growth scare” is likely to weigh on sentiment in the near term, but ultimately will work itself out (likely by 1Q19). We would wait for the dust to settle a bit before adding to positions.

FATDAZ Re earnings Goldman has a note out this morning that this October is the 3rd worst month for US stocks since GFC
BE11:18am

In terms of moving parts .....

BE11:19am

The 4Q revenue growth guidance of 10 - 20% Y/Y was below Street at the high - end and includes ~80bp FX Impact. The OI outlook for 4Q also was a tad light vs. consensus. 3Q international retail revenue growth slowed 600bp Q/Q to 15% ex - fx from Souq and the calendar shift for Dawali. 3-P revenue decelerated 400bps to 32% ex - fx and Online Stores was up 11% (above our +9 % estimate) but both continue to decelerate

FATDAZ My previous comments have been expunged lol
BE11:21am

The mid-point of Q4 op income guidance is ~25% below consensus expectations, but it's worth noting that Amazon has beaten Q4 op income guidance by an average of 94% over the past three years, suggesting that a typical beat would far exceed where consensus Q4 expectations were going into the quarter. While some investors may be disappointed with the deceleration in revenue growth, we are encouraged by the potential for ongoing margin expansion and bottom line upside. Reiterate OW on AMZN, our PT is now $2,050

Tom Dalgleish Has AMZN had bad quarters before?
Blackbag99 Does it matter though? Not yet, but it is a retailer that needs to eat 4 full walmarts in the next 7 years to justify todays valuation.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Here's Jefferies with the number soup:

BE11:27am

Rev growth remarkably stable ex-FX. CC gross revs grew 22% y/y in Q3, after 23% in both Q1 & Q2, which is impressive given gross rev run rate of $135Bn/yr. FX was a factor as tailwind of ~250-300bp y/y in Q1-Q2 turned into a headwind of ~50bp. This led to net revs $27.16Bn missing consensus by a small $130M (a miss of ~0.5%, as reported). We have lowered our FQ4 net rev est. slightly for FX, to $30.9Bn from $31.3Bn, or 19% y/y as reported vs. 21% previously. This looks conservative enough after Q3's +22%. Q4 should see seasonal strength in both the ad business as well as Other Revs (e.g., 3rd gen hardware just launched for the holidays).

BE11:28am

Nice progress on margins. NG op mgn 31.8% stepped up from 30.9% in Q2 and 30.7% in Q1, and beat JEFe/St. 31.5%/31.2%. These exclude the accrued performance fees related to equity gains and are relative to net revs (ex-TAC). Cash flow performance was also strong
- CFFO/FCF $13.2Bn/$7.9Bn vs. St. $10.2Bn/$5.8Bn, despite continued heavy investments. Strong int'l growth; no GDPR impact detected. EMEA revs grew 19% y/y ex-FX, same as in Q2, which we view as a positive given it appears to imply no negative GDPR impact. APAC continued to be strong: +30% y/y after 34% in Q2 (had 4% tougher comp in Q3).

Electric Dragon @Tom D lire is to read, lu is its past participle
11:28 am
BE11:28am

Other notable takeaways: 1) Waymo passed 10M miles of autonomous driving tests on public roads (up from 8M last qtr). Phoenix trials have been expanded to more people, some of whom are paying fares; Waymo is actively testing different pricing models ahead of the upcoming launch. 2) Paid clicks on Google properties grew 62% y/y, after 58% in Q2 & 59% in Q1. 3) As in Q2, Cloud was again the leading contributor to growth for Other Revs, ahead of Google Play.
Reasonable valuation. CY19 EV/EBITDA 11.0x is in line with NASDAQ Comp's 11.6x and S&P 500 10.5x. GOOGL is estimated to grow CY19 rev 20% at 46% EBITDA mgn vs. S&P500
5% at 21%, respectively (all using FactSet consensus). GOOGL's multiple has been stuck under 14x for the last 10 yrs and could expand if revs stay strong and margins rebound. Our 12-month PT of $1,450 (unchanged) is based on 14x EV/EBITDA applied to our sales estimates in 5-8 qtrs.

Tom Dalgleish Instructive that the easy days of tech growth could be ending
BE11:30am

(@Blackbag: where would Alphabet be cannibalising its own sales from?)

BE11:30am

And Cowen .....

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Another solid Q that reinforces our "core holding" view. And revenue
growth remains particularly impressive (if slightly decelerating this Q) versus our expectations over the past year, even as opportunities like more Maps monetization possibly still lie ahead. But we continue to believe Street margin expectations (220bps compression in FY18E, but 20bps of expansion in both FY19E/FY20E) are too aggressive, as mix continues to shift to YouTube, Hardware and Cloud. Reiterate Market Perform; the most likely thing to get us more proactive is Maps (or another DR) ad ramp.

There was a request for grey on the Valeo warning, which has hit all the autoparts makers. China worsening and WLTP in Europe causing even more OEM disruption than expected.

Airborne Cigar I can understand what the AMF said, but what does it mean? Is someone and his lawyer going to analyse it?
BE11:35am

Massive downgrades coming through due to confidence being shot. Here's socgen.

BE11:35am

Although Valeo’s 3Q18 revenue performance was respectable, the market
will inevitably focus on the further – and sharp – downward earnings
revision that it delivered at the same time. FY18 guidance for its
operating margin excluding equity accounted companies was cut from
“slightly below FY17’s 7.8%” to “between 6.2% and 6.5%” while the free
cash flow generation target was halved to €120-150m. We have reduced
our FY18, FY19 and FY20 operating margin estimates by 21%, 22% and
27%, which also reflects reduced visibility beyond this year. When
coupled with the sharp compression in supplier multiples since July, our
TP falls from €62 to €31. With a TSR of 10%, Valeo is now rated as Hold.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Valeo maintains that it was ahead of its peers when it warned in July about deteriorating market conditions in 2H18, but the severity of its latest earnings revision puts the onus on management to restore faith in what still has the hallmarks of a compelling industrial and equity story.

BE11:37am

Some talk of Valeo kitchen sinking its guidance, but I note the divi still looks rather vulnerable.

BE11:37am

Here's Caz.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

We tried to anticipate Valeo’s profit warning with our Q3 preview,
downgrading our estimates but yesterday’s guidance came 18% below our
FY18 and 10% below our FY19 guidance. There are several elements of
kitchen sinking guidance in FY18 guidance as well as several reversals
which lead to 10% earnings cut next year which is where our PT hinges. In
the light of the volatile WLTP transition and current China demand
slowdown Valeo’s guidance is more reasonable, but still we are finding
major areas where we would welcome improved disclosure; for example
more granular guidance on growth by region linked to OEM and vehicle to
understand the acceleration and deceleration of the business model. We
also find the current disclosure of Siemens Valeo JV limited, taking into
consideration the weight on the margin progression we would welcome a
separate P&L for this division or at least a CMD focusing on this division
next year.

BE11:38am

We are taking down our PT to €45 maintaining OW call. The key question
from investors remains the why now OW, as the investment case has not
changed over the past 6 months. We think the guidance has been kitchensinked,
earnings are unlikely to go below FY18 levels and despite the lack
of growth guidance for next year, we believe that if growth does normalize
next year (low single digit outperformance to global car production) and
Siemens Valeo JV losses narrow it would not be too complicated for Valeo
to return to the margin expansion trajectory in FY19.
